author: Kumar Buradikatti
text:
As many as 1,800 singers from six States with six different linguistic backgrounds collectively sang 108 devotional Kannada songs for six hours at the Sri Guru Raghavendra Mutt, Mantralayam, Andhra Pradesh, on Wednesday.

The performance that was inaugurated by Sri Subudhendra Tirtha, head and chief administrator of Sri Guru Raghavendra Mutt, at around 12.30 p.m. and ended by 6.30 p.m., earned an entry in the Telugu Book of Records. All the devotional songs were on Lord Anjaneya. The performance was organised by Dasa Sahitya Project of the Mantralayam mutt.

The artistes were from New Delhi, Maharashtra, Odisha, Telangana, Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka.

The maximum number of singers, 996, was from Andhra Pradesh, followed by Karnataka 458 and Maharashtra 241.

Most of the singers were women. Music keyboard, mridangam, tabla and violin were mainly used during the performance.

“We are excited. We do not know Kannada. But we practiced the Kannada songs with the help of Devanagari script and performed well at the event,” Anjali, a member of the Padmavathi Bhajan Mandali, Mumbai, said.

“We have been practising Dasa Sahitya for the last 14 years. We are glad that our 40-year-old Bhajan Mandali is part of a world-record performance now,” Geetha, member of Sri Raghavendra Bhajan Mandali, Mumbai, said.

Girirajacharya, pandit of the mutt, S.K. Srinivas Rao, manager of the mutt, K. Appannacharya and Narayana Das, director and deputy Director, respectively, of the Dasa Sahitya Project, were present.
title: A performance that finds a place in the record books
